Award.AwardTitle: ATD: Quantitative Methods for Estimating Sequencing Errors
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigators propose is to establish a general statistical methodology to
estimate error rates for any of the existing second-generation
sequencing technologies. They have identified an approach that is broadly
applicable, fast, and easy to implement. Important strengths are that it
only requires intensity data; it is applicable to the data types that
are typically shared publicly; and it does not require the availability
of a reference genome or genomes ---a key condition in threat detection
applications.

Sequencing is a technology to read small words made out of DNA or RNA.
In may applications across biology we need to identify words that occur
in a book where they are not supposed to be (for example mutations in
cancer or pathogens in the intestinal flora). Often these 'bad' words
are similar to other words which occur elsewhere in the book, differing
only by a letter or two. As seqeuncing is not free of errors, to know
whether we are seeing a bad word or a poorly read good word we need to
know how easy it is to misread a letter. This proposal is to assess
exactly this, with the goal of providing better foundations to all
scientific research that uses sequencing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research was conducted in response to NSF PROGRAM SOLICITATION 10-540 on
Algorithms for Threat Detection (ATD). It focused on three topics related to finding biological
threats by examining DNA samples that contain DNA molecules from multiple sources ---for
example a human host, the bacteria that normally and harmlessly live in it and external potentially harmful invaders. The topics are the following: 1) examining DNA samples is
prone to errors; differentiating human from other DNA based on subtle differences requires
quantifying the chance that these differences may be the result of errors. We developed
quantitative method to estimate error rates of widely used DNA sequencing technologies. Our approach does not require knowing the genomes of the bugs involved. 2) We then set out to find
statistical approaches to detect fragments of DNA from unknown species, mixed into large
collections of fragments from human or other DNA from harmless sources. We developed an innovative method that leverages
unusual patterns in the way DNA "letters" are ordered. 3) samples containing DNA from a large,
number of species pose a BigData challenge that requires approaches to condense information
into more a manageable size, for example by clustering. We developed methodology that support better statistical analysis
of these operations in microbiome data.

The broad impact of these activities is to bring us closer to reliably and efficiently identify
biological threats. There are collateral potential applications across other areas of biology and
biomedicine. For example 1) can be applied across all studies using sequencing and is also
applicable to the study of RNA; 2) has potential in early detection of cancer via "liquid biopsies"; and 3)
has applications to the study of any microbial community, whether pathogenic species are present or not.


In each of these activities the project's faculty trained and mentored postdoctoral fellows and
graduate students.


The remainder of this document provides additional details on the three component of the
project's outcome.


1) the program solicitation called for research to address challenges in genome sequencing
research, and specifically “development of quantitative methods and models to estimate errors
for the various sequencing platforms”. Our work established a general, flexible and robust
statistical methodology to estimate error rates for second-generation sequencing technologies.
The fundamental advance behind the proposed methodology is our observation that there is a
linear relationship between the frequency of short reads (tags) and the frequencies of their
’neighboring’ tags, where neighbors are defined by sequence similarity. This linear increase
reflects sequencing errors, as frequently occurring tags cast larger ’shadows’ of errors on
neighboring tags. Thus, regression of shadow counts on tag counts can provide a solution to the
challenge posed by the program solicitation. We investigated statistical and mathematical
properties of the shadow regression method. We implemented the methodologies in a
Bioconductor package and a parallel R implementation.  All tools are open source. Research
results were published in the journal "BMC Bioinformatics".


2) following participation in an ADT workshop, we identified an additional opportunity to leverage
our experience with alignment-free methods in pathogen detection for DNA sequencing data.
This is motivated by field-work in threat detection, where computing resources are limited and/or
sequencing data cannot be uploaded in full to cloud-based computing resources. We developed
statistical theory extending standard alignment-free methods to Markov structures, which
significantly increases detection ability. We derived general requirements on the detection of
rare contaminations in terms of the DNA read-size, the size of the DNA read-throughput and thedissimilarity of the contamination compared to host DNA. We were also able to characterize the
proportions of foreign DNA needed for alignment-free and genome-map-free detection to work.
The resulting manuscript is being revised for submission.


3) we branched out the the related field of microbiome studies. Human microbiome studies use
sequencing technologies to measure the abundance of bacterial species or Operational
Taxonomic Units (OTUs) in samples of biological material. Typically the data are organized in
contingency tables with OTU counts across heterogeneous biological samples. In the microbial
ecology community, ordination methods are frequently used to investigate latent factors or
clusters that capture and describe variations of OTU counts across biological samples. It
remains important to evaluate how uncertainty in estimates of each biological sample’s
microbial distribution propagates to ordination analyses, including visualization of clusters and
projections of biological samples on low dimensional spaces. We propose a Bayesian analysis
where similarity between microbial distributions is represented by latent factors that concentrate
in a low dimensional space. We use a shrinkage prior to tune the dimensionality of the latent
factors. The resulting posterior samples of model parameters can be used to evaluate
uncertainty in analyses routinely applied in microbiome studies. Specifically, by combining them
with multivariate data analysis techniques we can visualize credible regions in ecological
ordination plots. The resulting publication is posted in arxiv and is under review.
